question.title: junit import not working in IntelliJ IDEA
question.body:
I have this import in intelliJ IDEA:

import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.*;

and it says

cannot resolve symbol 'api'

package com.programming.techie;

import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.*;

class ContactManagerTest {

}

I have these dependencies in maven:

     <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-jupiter</artifactId>
        <version>5.13.1</version>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
        <version>5.10.0</version> <!-- Or the latest stable version -->
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

    <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-jupiter-engine</artifactId>
        <version>5.10.0</version> <!-- Or the latest stable version -->
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

answers.body:
To use

import static org.junit.jupiter.api.Assertions.*;

You only need to have the following in pom.xml

<!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.junit.jupiter/junit-jupiter-api -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
    <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
    <version>5.13.1</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>

Avoid using different versions of the junit-jupiter library.

You can do one of the two things.

  1. Remove the other junit dependencies (or)
  2. Make all the junit dependencies the same version in pom.xml

In case your error is not solved after doing this, try doing "Invalidate cache and restart" in IntelliJ and then do a maven reload.

After that, it should work fine.

Use just the Jupiter Aggregator Artifact

Your first dependency junit-jupiter is an aggregator artifact, meaning that artifact represents a group of other artifacts. Your other Jupiter artifacts are redundant.

When you specify junit-jupiter, you automatically get junit-jupiter-api, junit-jupiter-engine, and junit-jupiter-params.

  • junit-jupiter aggregator artifact gets you these three artifacts:
    • junit-jupiter-api
    • junit-jupiter-engine
    • junit-jupiter-params

All you need in your Maven POM file is:

<!-- https://mvnrepository.com/artifact/org.junit.jupiter/junit-jupiter -->
<dependency>
    <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
    <artifactId>junit-jupiter</artifactId>
    <version>5.13.1</version>
    <scope>test</scope>
</dependency>

If you want to use the Jupiter assertion facility at runtime, delete the scope element. See Maven Dependency Scopes at Baeldung.com.

The aggregator artifact was added to Jupiter later, after it first arrived. So this convenience is unfortunately not as widely known as it should be. You may see projects using the multiple Jupiter artifacts individually, but know that you can indeed replace them with the single aggregator artifact. Doing so makes your POM briefer, easier to read, and less prone to errors such as the incorrect mix of versions that troubled your own project.

First you are using different versions of JUnit Jupiter parts. You should use one version. That can be simply achieved by using the BOM's of JUnit Jupiter like this:

  <dependencyManagement>
    <dependencies>
      <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-bom</artifactId>
        <version>5.13.2</version>
        <scope>import</scope>
        <type>pom</type>
      </dependency>
      ...
    </dependencies>
  </dependencyManagement>

The next step is to really use the dependencies you need:

  <dependencies>
    <dependency>
      <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
      <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
      <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
    <dependency>
      <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
      <artifactId>junit-jupiter-params</artifactId>
      <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>
    ...
  </dependencies>

The first one required to run in general unit test using JUnit Jupiter (aka JUnit 5)... The second one is only required if you have parameterized tests. If not you can remove that one.

You should also use recent versions of maven-surefire-plugin and if you have integration tests you should use the maven-failsafe-plugin

A full working example can looked up here: https://github.com/khmarbaise/youtube-videos/tree/main/episode-2

question_comments.body: Soren: I´m a noob in testing so i wasn´t sure about which library is the correct one. The class ContactManagerTest is inside the test package. I pressed a key combination that automatically created the class in that package
Why are you mixing different versions of junit-jupiter libraries?

79682066.body: @FRafaelAlvarez - You commented "thanks, it worked". I am glad, but please do not add a comment on your question or on an answer to say "Thank you". Instead, take a look at What should I do when someone answers my question?. (Voting on an answer or accepting an answer are always optional - but they are encouraged).
